utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Brock? What are you doing?

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: Getting ready for surgery. What’s it look like?

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: You’re operating on my sister.

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: And my fiancé.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: You’re drunk. You could kill her.

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: It’s the only way to stop my hands from shaking. I need to drink. For Anna.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: What about… our baby.

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: Our… baby?

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Oh, my God! Are you okay? Brock, speak to me. Oh, my God. Um. I, I, I, I think he’s really hurt.

utterance.speaker: Director
utterance.content: Cut.

utterance.speaker: Technician
utterance.content: Uh, we can edit that word out…

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Uh, that was scary. I thought there for a second you were really –

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Then you gotta be the only one in the world who did. This is ridiculous.

utterance.speaker: Director
utterance.content: It was great, Evan.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: No it wasn’t. It was crap.

utterance.speaker: Director
utterance.content: The fans are gonna love it.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: The fans are crap. I’m crap. This whole damn show is crap! Sorry. Not your fault.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Um. Where are you going? My apartment’s on the West Side. Excuse me. You need to go the other way. Hey, did you hear what I said? What the hell is going on here? What do you want?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: An autographed picture would be nice. Oh… And I’m also gonna save your life.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: You might want to think about repositioning the crosswalk. It’s technically not a violation, but the closer they are to the entrance, the more likely they are to be used.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Makes sense. I actually wasn’t expecting you until next month...

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: That’s the problem with planned visits – administrators plan for them. The most recent New Jersey hospital accreditation requirements

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah. I’m familiar with –

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: Who was that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I have no idea. Shall we get started?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Just let me go. I won’t press charges. Forget the whole thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s probably true, seeing as how you have a brain tumor.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You’re that nut-job doctor that keeps calling my publicist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, I’m the nut-job head of diagnostic medicine.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I run every day. I don’t get headaches. I’m fine. So, if you don’t mind…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, I do mind. I don’t care if you die. But if Brock Sterling dies, Anna never finds out he’s the father of Marie’s baby.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Help!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Help! We’re gonna need a wheelchair… here. Look, in the last month your average line reading has slowed from 2.1 seconds to 2.9. You’re pausing more. Always at the same intervals – every seven to nine words. Which means you’re having trouble reading one side of the teleprompter. Which means a peripheral vision problem. Which means a tumor in your occipital lobe. Just one test. If there’s nothing wrong, I’ll take you right back home.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Make it cab fare. I don’t want you anywhere near my house.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Uh, just put it in my spot.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The accreditation board is here to protect us and our patients. So, in dealing with the on-site inspector, please behave as though it wasn’t also an enormous pain in the ass. Chase, Foreman, Cameron – up here, please. Why is House driving a limo.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Don’t know.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don’t have to know.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Don’t… care?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Wrong. Until this inspection is over, you’re back on House watch. Current case, past cases.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t have a current case.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I have a whole department.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Are you gonna fire us if we don’t?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was just – asking for your help. The last time I checked the ER, you had the best-kept charts in the building. The last time I checked the fourth floor janitor’s closet, I found House’s charts. He hasn’t filed anything since you left. Now, House may not care whether this hospital’s accreditation gets downgraded, but the people who sign my paychecks do. So, I repeat, current, past.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He doesn’t have a current case.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Did he tell you about the limo?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: So I just press this button every time I see a light?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It tells me where your blind spots are. So… the twins They’re gonna turn out to be yours, aren’t they.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I told you. I can’t talk about that stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you want to be done with this, right?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: One’s mine, one’s Julio’s.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I knew it. Julio knocked her up before her appendix burst. You got her after.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: How can you watch that stuff?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: ‘Cause it’s awesome.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: It’s preposterous. Not one real moment since I’ve been on the show.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: As opposed to shows that represent the world exactly the way it is, like… I can’t think of any.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hospital is being inspected and Cuddy dispatched you to keep an eye on me. I just parked a town car in an ambulance bay and, instead of ripping me one, Cuddy acted like she didn’t know me. It’s either an inspection or an aneurysm.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: What’s the test say?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: As I suspected, you have significant losses in the upper right quadrant of your visual field.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Are you serious?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it’s a joke. Two guys go into a bar and one has significant losses in the upper right quadrant of his visual field. And the other one says, ‘You’re gonna need an MRI to confirm the type and location of the tumor.’

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That readout says his vision’s fine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, it doesn’t.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yes, it does.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You lied to me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I kidnapped you. You’re surprised that I lied to you? It just means that the symptoms are intermittent.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You come near me again, I’m calling the police.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You kidnapped him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s sweet that I haven’t lost the ability to surprise you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you mocking me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: My back. My back is killing me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t care. Busy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Amber’s damn mattress.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well that sucks. Don’t buy a new one.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you being sarcastic? Because we are buying one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s incapable of doing anything that matters without turning it into a zero-sum game.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We’re buying a mattress for us.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow. I’m faster than you right now. It’s all about her and whatever hapless salesman wanders into her sights. She’s gonna lie, steal and trade your testes to get whatever she wants. Hold on. I just gotta do something before he dials the second ‘1.’ You’re going to end up humiliated, holding her purse and going home to sleep on a new mattress you hate.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What the hell are you doing?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He needs an MRI.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Give me one millimeter slices from the cortex down.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Any particular reason you decided to sedate a patient for a procedure that’s completely painless?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy has a history of violent outbursts during surgical procedures.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah, on TV. It’s Evan Greer. He’s the main stud on House’s soap. Frontal cortex looks clean. No tumors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Increase the magnification on the occipital lobe. You watch because you like or because I like?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I was unemployed. I –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Bzzt. Sorry. That’s not an answer, that’s an apology. If we’re ever to come out of the darkness, we have to be proud –

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Occipital, frontal and temporal lobes are clean. So’s the optic nerve. Definitely no tumors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s fine?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: And awake.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh, what should we tell him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See if you can talk him out of suing me.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: He kidnapped me. He drugged me.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Perhaps you should go out the back way.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I’m not going anywhere you people tell me to go.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It’s just, someone of your fame, uh… I figured fans…

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You’re trying to hide me. You don’t want me making a scene.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The hospital’s being inspected today.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: And you want me doing you a favor?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not us! Our Dean of Medicine. And House hates her. You’d be doing House a favor by complaining.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: This hospital is staffed with lunatics and criminals. Excuse me, where’s Dr. Cuddy? It’s my foot. What did he do to me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What did House do?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Nothing. I was with him the whole time.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: It’s numb. I can’t feel it. I can’t walk.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Foot numbness has a huge differential.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It gets a lot narrower when you add in peripheral vision problems.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which gets a lot wider when there’s no proof he ever had a vision problem.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So, House was wrong about the first symptom, but the guy just happened to develop a second, unrelated symptom a few hours later?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He already kidnapped and sedated a guy against his will. Makes sense he’d also do something to numb his foot so he couldn’t leave.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But it doesn’t make sense to include the symptom that he caused in a differential he’s so desperate to solve.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Unless he didn’t mean to cause it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Stick to the filing, sweetheart. Let the doctors do the doctoring. Either toxins or a vitamin deficiency –

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m guessing when you drugged him, you didn’t catch him and ease him to the floor. He could have pinched a nerve in his ankle when he fell. You need to run an EMG test for motor nerve entrapment or the inspector will own your ass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kutner, leave the room. Wait thirty minutes, come back and tell her the test was negative.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Is it okay if I use that time to do the test?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get out of here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: The rest of them can help me with all this stuff.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re busy. Which is really annoying because I wanted to be able to say they’re busy for no other reason than to screw with you. Research.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: So the nutjob was right?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Usually is.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: He said I was dying.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He’s wrong a lot, too. That’s why we do these tests. I bet it’s cool, you know, being the star of a hit TV show.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: It’s a daytime soap. It pretty much puts me one step above dinner theater.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Come on. You’re on TV every day. And who cares what the critics think. Women love soaps.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You get to take pride in your job. Feel good when you go home at night.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: You’re entertaining people.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I don’t care.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Then you’ve made a strange career choice.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Look, I’m pandering. I want to be a part of something that inspires people.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So quit. Find something inspiring and do it.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: It’s not that easy.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Why not?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Just isn’t.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: It’s my heart, doctor. It’s racing.

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: I’m sure it’s nothing. You’re a healthy woman, Marie.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Shouldn’t you examine me?

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: Why don’t you have Rico do it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can’t tell me you didn’t notice that pause.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: She’s never waking up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ah, this is a whole new experience in super high def. I had no idea Marie wore an underwire.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Does sound a little forced. Could be stiffening in his tongue which is a symptom of myxedema.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’s not the tongue, it’s the dialog. I think I dated that nurse, though. No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about the way he’s holding that stethoscope? His thumb and forefinger are meeting at an odd angle.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be demylenation from toxic exposure.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Back it up.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What’s this, the AV club?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s diagnostic. Everything’s under control.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Yeah, excellent job so far. House, outside.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Keep watching. You’ll never guess what Rico’s got in that box.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Rico doesn’t even know I’m alive.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You have an obsession with an actor or the character he plays. I feel for you. You need to work it out. But I need you to do it when the hospital’s accreditation and my job are not on the line.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want the star of the hottest daytime drama on TV to die in your hospital?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, I want you to cure him without committing any more felonies.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I can’t do my job if you’re going to tie my hands like that.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fifty-one weeks out of the year I let you run around like a monkey in a banana factory. All I’m asking is that you tone it for a few days.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I want that TV.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’re not bargaining.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want something. Either you’re bargaining or you’re begging.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Me keeping my job is good for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, but it’s better for you. I just want us to be equally happy.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: EMG was negative for nerve entrapment. Means the foot’s a real symptom. Could be vitamin deficiency.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or a toxin.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Or atherosclerosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Or a toxin.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Why is toxin a better idea?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Might not be. We’ll know after I’m finished searching his set and dressing room for medically relevant stuff. Gotta go. Need a decision.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re not going to cut your own throat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, that sounds like me. Test for heavy metals, organics, biotoxins and search the home.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I like the pillow top.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I like this one.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: Great taste. That model’s top of the line.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: How much is it?

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: $1,999. It’s a great price.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And, what about –

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: That’s too rich for us.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I don’t know. You think…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Honey, we can’t afford that. Not with the baby on the way.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: Congratulations. Your first?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: How about I knock a hundred bucks off. Maybe throw in free delivery.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Money is really tight right now. I’m a law clerk and my husband just got laid off. He has an interview today. Wish him luck.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: Good luck.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fingers crossed.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We might be able to afford $1,500.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: Well, I’d have to check with my manager.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Thanks. I appreciate it. Hold this, would you? 911 from work. Better go.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So am I getting the hard mattress or do I have to go to my job interview?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Whatever mattress you want. I’m fine either way.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You… Really?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Really. Just as long as I get to help you break it in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pack your manhood on ice. Maybe the hospital can reattach it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You were so wrong. She’s letting me choose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “You choose” does not mean you choose.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Really? Sounded like “you choose.” I suppose it’s possible she meant “House is soooo, so wrong.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a trap. It means “if you love me you’ll buy the one I want.”

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Amber doesn’t do passive-aggressive.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: People who do aggressive don’t like to limit themselves. Could a leaky space heater cause vision problems and numbness?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’d of gotten better at the hospital. It’s not a trap.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Did I hear a question mark at the end of that sentence?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, look, she’s –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Gotta go.

utterance.speaker: Salesman
utterance.content: Manager says I can do that price.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: The gin bottles are all gifts from fans. Brock Sterling drinks it on the show but Evan doesn’t drink at all. He’s on this whole health kick right now. Fruits, nuts – did you take those from his dressing room?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. You’re not going to marry Brock, are you? We’ve been waiting four years for him to make it official with Anna.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Are you really a doctor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Glioblastoma. Need more proof? So, no toxins on the set, how about his regular life? Unusual hobbies? Unsavory friends?

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: No. I’ve been out with him. He’s as vanilla as they come.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And by “out” you mean…?

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Well, I asked him on a date last month. We went out a few times but we weren’t right for each other.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too small or too large?

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: Is that medically relevant?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m a doctor and it’s relevant to me. So, yes.

utterance.speaker: Marie
utterance.content: We never got that far. We made out a while then he just said he should go home. He’s a real gentleman.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now that’d be interesting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s impotent. Steady diet of sunflower seeds causes a B6 toxicity, which causes an autonomic disregulation, which causes a wood-free existence.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: One bad night and a couple of sunflower seeds and he’s got autonomic disregulation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s more than just one. He can’t even remember the last time he was able to salute. It’s cool, huh?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: B6 wouldn’t show up on a tox screen and we didn’t find anything at the house.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So all we have to do is filter the B6 out of his blood. Prep him for plasmapheresis.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just because he didn’t salute doesn’t mean he can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And can you find out where that voice keeps coming from? And tell it to get out of my head.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The impotence could be psychological. He’s depressed. Hates his job.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Plasmapheresis has risks. We should have him spend the night in the sleep lab. See if he gets a reflex erection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Confirmation is for wimps and altar boys. We don’t need to wait for a reflex. If he can’t get engorged the way God intended, he can’t get engorged.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I’m not showing him my boobs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lack of response to your chest tells us nothing. Thirteen, show him… Where can I find a decent set of knockers around here?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Your porn’s in the second drawer.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: All set. Heart monitor, blood pressure monitor and the one on his junk.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: This is humiliating.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We’re going to close the blinds to give you some privacy. The instruments will let us monitor your response.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I don’t get this guy. He has the coolest gig ever but he’s miserable about it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: But he figures quitting won’t do him any good. Figures he’d be unhappy anywhere.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Our circumstances affect whether or not –

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You’re pretty happy in this job, right?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Sure.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Have you ever had a job where you were miserable?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I once sold men’s fragrances in a department store.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: And were you miserable?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: The pay was awful.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It was a miserable job, but you weren’t miserable.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So, what about you? Are you happy?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not particularly. Heart rate and BP are climbing.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Got some activity on the tumescence monitor as well.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: There’s nothing wrong with his naughty. It’s not B6 toxicity. Did he just… finish?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Sometimes, uh, when you haven’t, you know, for a while…

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: His heart rate’s through the roof – 220 and climbing.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He’s headed for cardiac arrest.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We shocked his heart back into sinus rhythm. He’s stable, at least for now.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Could be some sort of atypical septic reaction.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not without a fever.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Thus the word “atypical.”

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In that case, it could be an atypical bunion.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He used to smoke. Could be paraneoplastic syndrome caused by small cell lung cancer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He quit twenty years ago and his calcium levels are normal.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Could be Graves Disease. Extreme hyperthyroid disease leads to systemic problems including numbness, vision loss and cardiac arrest.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You want to be here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I have to be here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just say the word. I’ll fire Thirteen.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Just sign the forms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Smart move. I was bluffing. She’s right. We should fry the thyroid before it fries him.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Uh… I know it’s more exciting this way, but shouldn’t we confirm you’re right before destroying one of the most important glands in his body?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If that gland has drawn a bulls eye on his heart, then no.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nuking his thyroid puts him at risk for vascular lesions and all kinds of cancer. Protocol says we should do an iodine uptake test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: “We?” Anyone else want to run a useless test while Brock’s thyroid plots its next lethal move? It was rhetorical.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You were sure about B6 toxicity, too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House is right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously? I mean, I am, but you think so?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: If he goes into full-on thyroid storm, he’ll die. We gotta nuke his thyroid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hang up the phone.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Why? If we’re gonna nuke his thyroid…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We’re not nuking the guy’s thyroid without proof that it’s Graves. Do the iodine uptake test.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If House finds out…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When House finds out… We’ll have the test results. And we’ll either do his procedure, or we won’t.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just grabbing a snack.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You keep food in the morgue?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if I keep it in the lounge, everyone else eats it.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s ‘cause it’s everyone else’s food.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh. I thought it was just everyone else’s bags.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The accreditation board will light us on fire for this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: They’re not going to find out. Unless, of course, Conway planned on inspecting the morgue in, say… two minutes. Is that why you’re here?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re going to get me fired over a sandwich?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Over a TV. And you’re not gonna get fired because you’re gonna fold.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No, I won’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But you’re gonna push it. So we need a safe word. So you can signal your unconditional surrender. Call me “Sweet Sauce.” Dr. House. I don’t think we’ve met.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: Dr. Jaime Conway. I’ve heard your name.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Most people have. It’s also a noun. I sometimes come down here to relax, unwind. Maybe grab a –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Sweet Sauce.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s a nickname.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: An ironic nickname. Wow. It is almost two. Aren’t you supposed to be…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. Yeah. ‘Cause those sick, blind kids aren’t going to read to themselves. See ya. I recommend skipping C-26. Floater. Been in the river at least a week.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: Thanks for the warning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any time.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Doesn’t the doctors’ lounge have that same TV?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope. They’ve got a 12 inch, exactly like the one that used to be in here.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Files are done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll be doing a dance of joy just as soon as my leg is healed. Can you tilt that down?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know the paperwork annoys you, but patient records are important. You can’t just let them sit there.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I had to. In the name of science. I let the crap pile up and I see which team member is the most self-flagellating – breaks down, clears up the mess. Surprise was, it turned out to be you. Again. And you weren’t even registered as a competitor. You miss me.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: You miss me. You hired Thirteen to replace me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah. All pretty girls are fungible. You’re avoiding.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I miss the job. I miss running around playing private investigator. I miss... the puzzles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Seriously. I’ll fire Thirteen. Or Kutner, if you think Thirteen is hot.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I don’t miss you.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: That iodine left a really weird aftertaste.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That’s the tracer. We’ll have the images in a couple of minutes. You must do okay with women, huh?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: I already asked him that.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: It’s not all it’s cracked up to be.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He feels unfulfilled.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I doubt it.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I’m lying?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I used to be a plastic surgeon. I’d talk about my work as shallow and meaningless. Truth is, I loved every boob job, every tummy tuck. Meaning doesn’t mean that much.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: But you’re not a plastic surgeon anymore.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It’s complicated.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Are you happier?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It’s complicated.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: His thyroid looks normal.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: So that’s good news, right?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Everything look too bright to you?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It could be the monitor.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It’s not the monitor. It’s the iodine. It’s everywhere. His body’s not filtering it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: His kidneys are failing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I told you to nuke his thyroid.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It’s a good thing we didn’t. Kidney failure means it wasn’t graves.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, your test screwed me and our patient’s kidneys. You practically poisoned him with iodine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which he could have handled easily if his kidneys were healthy. All we did was reveal a new symptom. Usually you’re all for that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Must be the rancid tinge of betrayal that’s put me off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You were wrong.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So tell me to my face. You never hesitated before. The Board’s turned you into a coward.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I did it because it was the right thing to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You did it to pass an inspection.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Does it matter? Kidney failure on top of the other symptoms points to an autoimmune condition which means that any of his other organs could be next. We’ve already started dialysis. We need to run ANAs for autoimmune.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re right. You and the team, go measure the ceilings.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Accreditation board guidelines state that no object can be less than 18 inches from the ceiling. Make sure we’re in compliance.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s nothing in our office that would be less than…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t mean us. I mean the whole hospital.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Let’s see how this baby handles.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You bought the firm mattress.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I thought that’s the one you wanted.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It was. Why would you do that?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Because… Is this a trick question?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I left it up to you. You were supposed to get the one you wanted.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I got the one you wanted because I love you.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: No. You did it because that’s what you do. With all your ex-wives you did whatever they wanted because it was easier and you ended up resenting them. Don’t you dare do that to me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What? Take care of you?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Have you met me? I can take care of me. I need you to take care of you. I have work to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You made it to page 8. Mysterious hospital visit for soap doc.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Wow. I’ll be sure to send my Mom a copy. They told me I have an autoimmune disease, like lupus or sarcoidosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s what we’re here to find out.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: You really as good as everyone seems to think you are?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you really as miserable as everyone seems to think you are?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I just want to do something that matters.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing matters. We’re all just cockroaches, wildebeests dying on the river bank. Nothing we do has any lasting meaning.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: And you think I’m miserable.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you’re unhappy on the plane, jump out of it.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: I want to but… I can’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mmm. That’s the problem with metaphors. They need interpretation. Jumping out of a plane is stupid.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Well, what if I’m not in a plane? What if I’m just in a place I don’t want to be?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s the other problem with metaphors. Yes, what if you’re actually on an ice cream truck and outside are candy and flowers and virgins. You’re on a plane! We’re all on planes. Life is dangerous and complicated and… it’s a long way down.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: So you’re afraid of change?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you’re afraid to change. You’d rather imagine that you can escape instead of actually try. ‘Cause if you fail, then you got nothing. So you’ll give up the chance of something real so you can hold onto hope. The thing is, hope is for sissies.'

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: When I get out of here, I’m not gonna be afraid anymore. I mean, how many guys get a second chance?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too many. Half the people I save don’t deserve a second chance.

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Now that I’ve got mine, I’m gonna set things right. I’m gonna start by being a better father to you. And to your sister.

utterance.speaker: House and Evan
utterance.content: And to your other sister.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You realize you’re reciting lines from last season?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: We’re gonna do all the things I promised. Just help me get out of this bed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Cooling blankets in here. This guy’s brain is about to boil. Do you know where you are? What’s your name?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Dr. Brock Sterling.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Fever rules out autoimmune. He’s septic. He’s got a massive infaction.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We’ve got him on broad-spectrum antibiotics but he’s slipped from delirium into a coma.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good news is the last time Brock was in a coma, he fathered two children.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We need to identify the infection and get him on more targeted med, fast.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: What about pneumococcus? Causes heart problems and sepsis.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Not with the neuropathies in his foot and eyes. What about tetanus? It fits.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He had a tetanus booster last year. Lyme disease?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He would have been sore all over.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: There’s a thousand infections that could have caused this. We can start testing but he’ll be dead before the cultures grow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Unless it’s a fungus. We could see that under a microscope.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Test him for fungi, parasites, all creatures great and small.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To lie down. I need to think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could be rat bite fever. But his glands aren’t swollen. Which one are you gonna get?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She told me to get the one I want.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So get it. Listeria explains the sepsis, possibly also the heart problem.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: But not the numbness.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If the listeria caused encephalomyelitis which then caused the numbness.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I want a waterbed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’ve always wanted one. I know it’s ridiculous. It’s just… There’s something nice about the thought of being rocked to sleep in water. No mocking? No Freudian analysis of how the waterbed is really a great big vagina I want to crawl into?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m ignoring you because you make me sad. He’s on ampicillin. Which means if it’s listeria he would have shown some improvement.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It’s a whole… thing. You need special sheets and insurance and –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who cares? You wanted one your whole life. You’re a grown up. You can afford it. Stores sell them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Most adults don’t go through life the way you do, House, indulging our every whim.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t deserve to be happy.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: And yet I am. You?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It is stupid. Live the dream, Wilson.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s not an infection. It’s an allergy. That’s why it’s not responding to antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This isn’t a soap opera, House. People don’t just wake up from comas the second you give them drugs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Especially if we give them the wrong drugs. What’d the tests say?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It was negative for fungus and parasites. But that doesn’t mean–

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The more infections we rule out, the more likely it is that it’s not an infection.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He has no history of allergies or asthma. Most importantly, none of his symptoms remotely resemble an allergic reaction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Allergens could trigger an allergic vasculitis. That would explain the symptoms.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: One in a million times. Septic infection always explains his symptoms.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But an infection is never resistant to every antibiotic.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: An infection is rarely resistant –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And allergy never responds to antibiotics. Never beats rarely. QED I won. There were chrysanthemums in his dressing room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: My God. Why didn’t you say he’d been exposed to plant life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chrysanthemums contain pyrethrins, a neurotoxin and a know allergen.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He has an infection. If we give him steroids, we’ll kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He has an allergy. If we don’t give him steroids, we’ll kill him.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not as fast.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fast enough. We don’t have time for the rest of the tests. We have to do something. And what we’re doing right now isn’t working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A hundred milligrams methylprednisilone.

utterance.speaker: Pharmacist
utterance.content: Patients’ names?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s one patient.

utterance.speaker: Pharmacist
utterance.content: You want to give one patient a hundred milligrams? That’ll jump-start a car.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perfect. The patient’s in a ’69 Ford Coma.

utterance.speaker: Pharmacist
utterance.content: Anything over 50 milligrams, I need a sign-off from Dr. Cuddy. It’s protocol. And the inspector’s here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I am 99% certain that she’ll consent. For the sake of the 1%, why don’t I just…

utterance.speaker: Pharmacist
utterance.content: You’re not allowed back here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, tell the inspector he can put it on my tab.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: 100 milligrams of methylprednisilone is an overdose.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We were wrong about the infection. He’s suffering from a severe allergic reaction.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The team hasn’t finished the test for allergy. His symptoms don’t –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In rare cases… Trust me. At the end of this conversation, I’m right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Then confirm it. Get a blood test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What is it about this severe and deepening coma that makes you think we got time for protocol?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Protocol has saved your patient from having his thyroid destroyed and his blood drained.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you think I’m wrong, tell me I’m wrong. Don’t talk about protocol.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: My job’s on the line. You’re job is on the line.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay. Here’s what you do. You wait three minutes, then you call security. By the time they get here and lock me up, I’ll be done. He gets to live and your ass gets to be covered.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: If he dies, let me know. So I can pack my things.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Tests are negative. Patient’s negative for all floral allergies. I’m gonna restart the antibiotics… if he’s still alive.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Ampicillin, 2 grams IV.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why? The steroids worked. House was right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The test was negative.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He was still right. It was an allergy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To what?

utterance.speaker: Evan
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I was wrong. You should have stopped me.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: I heard about House’s patient. Bold move. And you backed him.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: He was right.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: He wasn’t even in the same neighborhood as right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: The patient’s alive.

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: Okay. The rules exist because 95% of the time, for 95% of the people, they’re the right thing to do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And the other 5%?

utterance.speaker: Conway
utterance.content: Have to live by the same rules. Because everybody thinks they’re in that 5%. Okay. I notice that, uh, Dr. Chase…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: What are you doing out here?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I can’t sleep. I hate the waterbed.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I actually kind of like it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No. It’s awful. We’re returning it tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Okay. I’m glad you got it, though.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Me too. I hope they’ll take it back.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: They will.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: You promised me you’d stop drinking.

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: Of course I’m drunk, Anna. They told me you’d never wake up from that coma.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: But how could you get engaged to my sister?

utterance.speaker: Brock
utterance.content: We fell in love. What do you want from me Anna? I’m just a man.

utterance.speaker: Anna
utterance.content: And I’m just a woman. And as thrilled as I am about The Lady Slipper being the best nightclub Port Lawrence has ever seen, doesn’t compare to the happiness that I feel when –

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Hello?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t hang up. What was the verdict?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You should have been fired.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good night, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There are bubbles in his glass.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Can’t this wait until –

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My patient is allergic to quinine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And you got this from bubbles?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The symptoms started two months ago. It’s also when Brock started downing gin and tonics like a Brit staving off malaria. The gin was fake. The tonic was real.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And tonic water is loaded with quinine. Huh. Nice job.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You should’ve been fired.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m taking back the TV.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I saved his life.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That wasn’t the deal.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The contract clearly stated no takesy backsides.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good night, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What are you wearing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Good night, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good night, Cuddy.
